awd_titl_txt: A Robust Framework for Modeling Preferences and its Applications in Revenue Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Modeling customer preferences is a fundamental challenge in estimating demand in revenue management problems since the uncertain demand crucially depends on the substitution behavior of the customers. Such modeling is especially difficult as the preferences are latent and unobservable. The broad goal of this project is to develop a tractable data-driven approach for modeling preferences that is robust to model selection errors, and develop efficient algorithms for related decision problems. This research aims at developing foundational theory for preference modeling that has potential of significant impact in practice. To facilitate the dissemination of this work to maximize societal impact, the PI will focus on: i) training of students through research and integration of the results from this research into core graduate curriculum, ii) increasing the involvement of undergraduate students in research through summer REU projects, iii) increasing the societal impact through outreach programs for local high-schools including Society for Women in Engineering (SWE) and Harlem School Partnership (HSP) for STEM Education with particular focus on increasing the participation of underrepresented minorities and iv) working with industry towards application of this research in practice.

The main focus of this project is to study a Markovian framework for modeling preferences. This framework of modeling choice is simple yet very powerful and amenable to strong generalizations to capture a rich class of preference models. The PI aims to consider two broad directions in this project including: i) using the framework of Markov chain transitions to model a rich class of substitution behavior, and ii) using a Markov chain over an exponentially large state space of preferences to model a class of distribution over permutations such as Mallows and maximum entropy distributions more generally. Efficient estimation and optimization algorithms over these models would result in the theoretical foundations for a tractable data-driven approach to choice modeling. With the availability of large amount of data in today's world, such an approach has the potential of significant impact in many applications.

por.por_cntn:
Assortment optimization is an important problem that arises in many industries such as retailing and airlines. In such settings, the goal is to select an optimal subset of products to offer to maximize the expected revenue under an uncertain demand that is significantly affected by the substitution behavior of customers. Therefore, modeling customer preferences is one of the fundamental problems in this area in order to develop accurate demand models.

 

The broad goal of this project was to develop a tractable data-driven framework for modeling choice that is robust to errors in model selection. Modeling preferences is particularly challenging due to the fact that the preferences are latent and unobservable in data. We only observe the eventual choices of customers and not their preference lists. There is a fundamental tradeoff between the complexity of a choice model in capturing a rich substitution behavior and the tractability of the associated estimation and optimization problems. However, even if we ignore the tractability issues associated with estimation and optimization over a particular model, one of the key challenges in choice modeling is to find the ``right model'' to describe the preferences and substitution behavior. Errors in model selection can lead to significant errors in demand predictions and subsequently highly suboptimal decisions.

 

One of the main contributions of this project is to develop a tractable robust data-driven framework for revenue management and resource allocation problems. In particular, the PI builds upon his prior work on a Markov chain based choice model and studies both the estimation as well as assortment optimization problem that address the uncertainties in the parameter estimates. Under certain rectangularity assumptions, we show that the robust assortment optimization problem can be solved efficiently. In another related direction, we also consider the problem of computing optimal policies in Markov Decision Processes (MDP) that are robust to uncertainties in the transition probability parameters. Specifically, we consider uncertainty sets for the transition probabilities that are not necessarily rectangular unlike prior work in the literature in this area, and therefore, can model more realistic settings. We consider a factor model for transition probabilities where the transition probabilities out of a given state-action pair are a linear combination of a small number of factors and we consider uncertainty over these factors, and show that the worst-case optimal policy can be computed efficiently.

 

Building upon this work, we use the framework of factor model uncertainty in a healthcare setting to study the  problem of finding robust policies for proactive transfer to ICU for patients which account for uncertainty in statistical estimates due to data limitations when optimizing to improve overall patient care. In addition to the theoretically studying the structure of optimal robust policies, we also present computational experiments using a dataset of hospitalizations at 21 KNPC hospitals, and present empirical evidence of the sensitivity of various hospital metrics (mortality, length-of-stay, average ICU occupancy) to small changes in the parameters. Our work provides useful insights into the impact of parameter uncertainty on deriving simple policies for proactive ICU transfer that have strong empirical performance and theoretical guarantees.

 

In this project, the PI also studies online assortment and resource allocation problems where the goal is to design robust policies with provable theoretical guarantees to allocate a fixed set of resources when demand is revealed sequentially. In particular, we consider the problem of online bipartite matching with stochastic rewards arising from the stochasticity of the proposed match realizing. Such a problem arises in many applications and has been studied extensively. We give an optimal algorithm for the online matching problem with stochastic rewards. We also consider the online allocation problem when the resources are reusable. We develop a priority based allocation rule and show that it gives a (1-1/e)-competitive ratio for the adversarial arrival model under reasonable assumptions of the usage distributions. Please see the final report for detailed discussion about the significant results obtained in the project.

 

In addition to advancing our theoretical understanding, the PI has strived to have a positive impact at various other levels in this project that includes: i) the dissemination of research done in this project to the real-world and ii) the training of graduate and undergraduate students in research and teaching which is an extremely important link in creating a sustainable cycle of research and its dissemination to practice, and iii) increasing the societal impact through outreach programs for local high-schools (neighbors.columbia.edu) including Society for Women in Engineering (SWE) and Harlem School Partnership (HSP) for STEM Education with particular focus on increasing the participation of underrepresented minorities.
